level1_survival.explanation: Universal emphasis. Essential for daily chat.
The god-tier word for any intense emotion.

level1_survival.example: Meccha suki. (I love it so much.)

level1_survival.explanation: Attached to adjectives to show intense emotion.
level1_survival.example: Kawai-sugiru. (So cute I can't handle it.)
A: Nemui. B: Sorena. (A: Sleepy. B: Fact.)

level1_survival.explanation: Used when something is funny or ironic.
Used when someone/something is bothering you.

level1_survival.example: Sore kiku to mukatsuku. (That makes me mad.)

level1_survival.explanation: Used for physical tiredness or laziness.
level1_survival.example: Jugyou darui. (Class is such a hassle.)

level1_survival.explanation: Used for a tough schedule or situation.
level1_survival.example: Kono shift wa kitsui. (This shift is harsh.)
Futsuu ni oishii. (It's actually pretty good.)

level1_survival.explanation: The polite way to say 'it sucks'.
level1_survival.example: Kono fuku wa bimyou. (This outfit is meh.)

level1_survival.explanation: When a task is a piece of cake.
Take it easy or do it carelessly.
The most used word in restaurants.

level1_survival.example: Wan-chan ikeru! (Maybe we can make it!)
Saifu wasureta, tsunda. (Forgot my wallet, I'm done.)

level1_survival.explanation: Casual way to say you made a mistake.
level1_survival.example: Maji de misutta! (I really messed up!)

level1_survival.explanation: Canceling plans at the last second.

level1_survival.example: Idea wo pakurareta. (My idea was stolen.)

level1_survival.explanation: For amazing skills or terrible shock.
level1_survival.example: Ima no play, egui! (That play was insane!)
Mental kita wa. (That really got to me.)

level2_youth_vibes.explanation: Used for sunsets, old songs, or deep vibes.
level2_youth_vibes.example: Kono kyoku emoi. (This song hits different.)

level2_youth_vibes.explanation: To hang out and relax in a cool way.
level2_youth_vibes.example: Cafe de chiru. (Chilling at a cafe.)

level2_youth_vibes.explanation: Feeling great after eating good food.
level2_youth_vibes.example: Ramen tabete yuushou. (Ate ramen and won at life.)
Kare wa rebechi. (He is on another level.)
Kore wa bae-ru ne. (This looks great in photos.)

level2_youth_vibes.explanation: Chinese reading of 'Suki'. Trendy on SNS.
level2_youth_vibes.example: Kono visual, hao. (Love these visuals.)
Maji de supadari. (He's the perfect guy.)
Gamer-kaiwai. (The gamer circle.)
Aitsu you-kya da ne. (He's a real extrovert.)
Wai wa in-kya dakara. (Since I'm an introvert...)

level2_youth_vibes.explanation: A subculture fashion; also implies complex personality.
level2_youth_vibes.example: Jirai-kei fashion.
Kono shashin kako-sugi. (This is too filtered.)
Twitter de bazutta. (Went viral on Twitter.)

level2_youth_vibes.explanation: Subtly hinting at a relationship on SNS.
level2_youth_vibes.example: Kore niowase da yo ne? (Is this a hint?)
Mount torareta. (He flexed on me.)
Riatotsu shite mita. (Tried meeting them IRL.)

level2_youth_vibes.explanation: A word that has a huge impact.
level2_youth_vibes.example: Sore pawa-wa da wa. (That's a strong phrase.)
Meccha oshan! (So stylish!)

level2_youth_vibes.explanation: Buying only because it looks cool/cute.
level2_youth_vibes.example: Pake-gai shita. (Bought it for the box.)
Test yabai, pien. (Failing the test, sad.)
Pien koete paon. (Beyond sad.)
Kore maji bimyo-i. (This is really meh.)
Kyou no ore musou shiteru. (I'm unstoppable today.)
Yaba-mi ga fukai. (The craziness is deep.)

level2_youth_vibes.explanation: Historically about mental health, now a vibe.
level2_youth_vibes.example: Kanojo wa menhera. (She's very needy.)
Hobo hobo dekita. (It's pretty much done.)

level2_youth_vibes.explanation: Best friends who are always together.
level2_youth_vibes.example: Uchira niko-ichi. (We're a pair.)

level2_youth_vibes.explanation: People who post selfies on X/TikTok.
level2_youth_vibes.example: Jidori-kaiwai no hito.
Maji de tsumi da wa. (I'm totally done.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: The character or person you support the most.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Oshi ga toutoi. (My fave is so precious.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Used when something is so pure/perfect it feels holy.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Kono couple, toutoi. (This couple is divine.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Usually 'Goiryoku shinda' (I have no words).
level3_otaku_passion.example: Goiryoku shinda. (My vocabulary is dead / No words.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Being so moved you can't act like a normal human.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Genkai otaku. (An otaku at their emotional limit.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: When official content doesn't match your headcanon.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Kore wa kaishaku-chigai da wa. (This isn't right.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Falling deep into a fandom or hobby.
level3_otaku_passion.example: VTuber no numa ni hamaru. (Falling into the VTuber swamp.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Visiting real-life locations from an anime.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Seichi-junrei ni iku. (Going on an anime pilgrimage.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Supporting the whole group instead of just one member.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Watashi wa hako-oshi desu. (I love the whole group.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: An episode with legendary quality or plot.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Konshuu wa kamikai datta. (This week was legendary.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Official updates or news (e.g., 'Kyoukyuu ga ooi').
level3_otaku_passion.example: Kyoukyuu ga oosugiru. (Too much new content!)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Trying to get friends into your favorite series.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Oshi wo fukyou suru. (Spreading the word about my fave.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: A space in your room dedicated to character goods.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Saidan wo tsukuru. (Building a character altar.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Flat character stands. The most common modern merch.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Akusta to issho ni shashin toru. (Photos with my standee.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Short for 'Nuigurumi'. Often taken to cafes.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Nui-dori. (Taking photos of plushies.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Items that represent a character (e.g., their colors).
level3_otaku_passion.example: Oshi-gainen color. (The color of my favorite character.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Watching a show exactly when it broadcasts.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Riatai chuu. (Watching it live right now.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Fans who have been there since the beginning.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Watashi wa kosan da yo. (I'm a veteran fan.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Someone who just joined the fandom.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Shinzan desu, yoroshiku. (I'm new here.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Short for 'Daredemo Daisuki'. A bit of a flirt/fickle fan.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Kare wa DD dakara. (He falls for everyone.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Getting a CD/game a day before official release.
level3_otaku_passion.example: New album wo furage. (Got the album early.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Going to every single performance of a tour.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Tour zentsuu suru. (Going to every concert.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Buying many copies of one CD to support the artist.
level3_otaku_passion.example: CD wo 50-mai tsunda. (Stacked 50 copies of the CD.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Artists on SNS who draw legendary fan-art.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Kono kamieshi, maji yabai. (This artist is a god.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: The actual place where the event is happening.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Kyou wa genba ni imasu. (I'm at the venue today.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Traveling to another city just for a concert.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Osaka made ensei suru. (Expedition to Osaka for the show.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: Waiting for a stream or sale to start.
level3_otaku_passion.example: 21-ji kara taiki. (On standby from 9 PM.)

level3_otaku_passion.explanation: When something is so good you feel like you've died.
level3_otaku_passion.example: Egao mite shouten. (Saw that smile and ascended.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: The modern 'www'. Because 'w' looks like grass.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Kore wa kusa. (That's hilarious.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Even funnier than 'Kusa'. A field of grass.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Daisougen fukahi. (Can't help but laugh.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Acting tough or cool online.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Net de ikiru. (Acting tough on the internet.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Insult for people who don't know basic net facts.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Konna no mo shiranai no? Joujaku da na. (You don't know? Noob.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Impossible traps that kill you the first time.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Kono boss, shoken-goroshi da. (This boss is a trap.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Internet sleuths who find locations/identities.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Tokutei-han hayai wa. (The sleuths are fast.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Sharing someone's info/ID to shame them.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Sarashi-age. (Exposing post.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: A massive online backlash/scandal.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: SNS de enjou shiteru. (It's blowing up/flaming on SNS.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: The voice actor or the real person running an account.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Naka-no-hito nante inai yo. (There's no one inside.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Someone who watches streams but never comments.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Wai wa miru-sen desu. (I'm just here to watch.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Directly messaging or joining someone's stream.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Dentsu-totsu. (Raid via Discord/Phone.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Playing with random people online, not friends.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Nora de rank-match. (Playing ranked with randoms.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: When a strong player carries a weak teammate.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Master ni carry sareta. (Got carried by a Master.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Actions meant to irritate the opponent.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Aori-play wa yamete. (Stop taunting/trolling.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: A person or topic that causes instant trouble.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Aitsu maji de jirai da wa. (That guy is a total landmine.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: A private/locked SNS account.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Kagi-aka de tsubuyaku. (Tweet on my private account.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Having your account banned by the platform.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Aka-ban sareta. (I got banned.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: When the game server goes down.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Saba-ochi shite keta. (Got kicked because server crashed.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Camera distance so close it makes fans blush.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Kono angle wa gachikoi-kyori. (This is too close!)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Respectful suffix for reliable/notable people.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Kaisetsu-niki. (Explainer-bro / The guy who explains.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Sarcastic term for long, complaining SNS posts.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Okimochi-hyoumei kitar. (The long complaint has arrived.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Someone who pretends to be a long-time fan.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Niwaka wa damattore. (Poseurs, be quiet.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: A masterpiece game.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Maji de kamige! (Literally a god-tier game!)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Someone using illegal tools in games.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Cheater uzasugi. (Cheaters are so annoying.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Giving money to streamers (Super Chat).
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Nagesen de oshi wo sasaeru. (Support my fave with tips.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Short highlights from a long stream.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Kirinuki-douga de miru. (Watch it via clipped highlights.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: What streamers call their audience.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Listener no minna, ohayou. (Good morning to all my listeners.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Fans who obsessively protect a streamer.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Aitsu no kakoi wa kowai. (His simps are scary.)

level4_net_streaming_game.explanation: Someone who actively hates/attacks a person.
level4_net_streaming_game.example: Anti-comment wa through. (Ignore hater comments.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: The most common and cool way for men to refer to themselves.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Ore no ban da. (It's my turn.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Used by boys or men who want to sound humble or gentle.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Boku mo iku yo. (I'll go too.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Standard for women. For men, it sounds professional/formal.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Watashi ga yarimasu. (I will do it.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Used by athletes or disciplined types. Sounds a bit stiff but cool.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Jibun, bukyou desu kara. (I'm a clumsy person.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: A softer, more feminine version of 'Watashi'.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Atashi wa kocchi! (I'll take this one!)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Common among young girls. Originally a Kansai dialect vibe.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Uchira saikou! (We are the best!)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Standard 'net-speak' for 'Me'. Originally from Kansai male dialect.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Wai no kachi ya! (It's my win!)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Extremely narcissistic. Used by anime villains or confident jerks.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Ore-sama no toori da! (Make way for the Great Me!)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Used by pampered children or ironically by adults acting cute.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Boku-chan, nemui. (I'm sleepy.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Used by elderly men or wise masters in anime.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Washi no deban ja. (It is my turn to act.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Archaic. Used by characters who follow the way of the sword.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Sessha wa samurai degozaru. (I am a samurai.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Used by female rebels or tomboys in fiction.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Atai ni makashina! (Leave it to me!)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Sounds pompous and old-fashioned. Famous from 'I am a Cat'.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Wagahai wa neko de aru. (I am a cat.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Sounds rustic, energetic, and cute. Often used by animal mascots.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Oira mo asobu! (I wanna play too!)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Famous because of Goku. Sounds raw and powerful.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Ora wakuwaku suru zo! (I'm getting excited!)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Very archaic. Used by humble but serious samurai characters.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Soregashi no misu degozaru. (It was my mistake.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Used by high-class archaic female characters or empresses.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Warawa wa manzoku ja. (I am satisfied.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: The 'Royal We'. Used by Demon Kings or ancient emperors.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Yo wa ningen ga suki da. (I like humans.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Very literary. Used by characters with a 'God' complex.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Ware koso ga kamii da. (I am the god.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Used on X/Twitter to talk about oneself objectively or funnily.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Wai-shi, kyou mo zangyou. (Mr. Me is working late again.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: A heavily slurred version of 'Atashi'. Peak Tokyo girl vibe.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: A-shi, maji de kireta. (I was seriously pissed.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Used by police characters in anime/manga.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Honkan ga taiho suru! (I shall arrest you!)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Used in formal letters or by intellectual/stiff men.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Shousei no kenkai desu. (It is my humble opinion.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Historically only used by the Japanese Emperor. Peak authority.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Chin wa yurusan. (I shall not forgive this.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Humble way for commoners to speak in old Tokyo.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Asshi ni wa muri desu. (That's impossible for me.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Ultra-polite. Used by high-class ladies or in big business.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Watakushi ga go-annai shimasu. (I shall guide you.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Used by characters who pretend to be from the West.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Me no idea wa perfect ne! (My idea is perfect!)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: A nerdy way to refer to oneself in online forums.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Jibun-shi, kore suki. (I like this.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Used by 'Oiran' characters in historical dramas.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Achiki wa shiranai nushi. (I wouldn't know.)

level5_persona_pronouns.explanation: Literally 'stupid me'. Used by old-fashioned humble men.
level5_persona_pronouns.example: Gusei no itaru tokoro. (It's due to my lack of wisdom.)

level6_yakuza.explanation: A loud, aggressive shout used to stop someone or scold them. Feels intimidating and old-school.
level6_yakuza.example: Kora! Nani shiten da! (Hey! What do you think you‚Äôre doing?)
level6_yakuza.prompt: Gekiga style. Extreme close-up of a terrifying yakuza man shouting aggressively. Spit flying, veins popping on forehead, intense angry eyes. High contrast shadows, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: In tough-guy slang: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt take me lightly.‚Äù Strongly implies disrespect and provocation.
level6_yakuza.example: Ore o nameteru no ka? (Are you underestimating me?)
level6_yakuza.prompt: Yakuza movie anime style. Low angle shot looking up at a thug in a suit who is looking down at the camera with a disdainful, threatening sneer. Cigarette smoke, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: Taking responsibility properly‚Äîoften with a heavy, underworld vibe (not just saying sorry).
level6_yakuza.example: Kejime tsukeyou ka. (Let‚Äôs settle this properly.)
level6_yakuza.prompt: Serious drama anime style. A solemn atmosphere in a tatami room. A man in a white kimono sitting formally on his heels (seiza), staring at a short sword wrapped in white cloth on the floor. Tension, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: Slang for normal society‚Äîespecially used by people talking from a prison context.
level6_yakuza.example: Shaba no kuuuki wa umai na. (Air in the outside world feels good.)
level6_yakuza.prompt: Cinematic anime style. A silhouette of a man stepping out of a heavy prison gate into blinding bright sunlight. Freedom atmosphere, dust particles in the air, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: A sudden group assault on a rival place. Very yakuza/underworld term.
level6_yakuza.example: Kachikomi ikuzo! (We‚Äôre raiding them!)
level6_yakuza.prompt: Dynamic action anime style. A group of men in black suits sprinting down a hallway, kicking a door open. Debris flying, motion blur, intense rage, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: Hard-boiled slang meaning to fire a gun. Very noir/crime-fiction vibe.
level6_yakuza.example: Yattara, hajiku zo. (If you do it, I‚Äôll shoot.)
level6_yakuza.prompt: Film noir anime style. A man in a fedora hat holding a handgun with smoke rising from the barrel. His face is hidden in shadow. Rainy city background at night, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: Your public dignity and pride‚Äîespecially ‚Äúdon‚Äôt embarrass me‚Äù energy.
level6_yakuza.example: Mentsu tsubusuna. (Don‚Äôt ruin my reputation.)
level6_yakuza.prompt: Seinen manga style. A dignified boss adjusting his necktie in front of a mirror. Sharp suit, stoic expression, aura of pride and honor, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: Short, rough slang for the police. Often used in crime fiction.
level6_yakuza.example: Satsu ga kiteiru. (The cops are coming.)
level6_yakuza.prompt: Dark urban anime style. Red and blue police siren lights reflecting on wet pavement at night in the rain. A blurry figure running away in the distance, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: A sudden police search/raid of a place. Feels tense and chaotic.
level6_yakuza.example: Gasa-ire ga haitta. (They did a raid.)
level6_yakuza.prompt: Suspense anime style. An office room turned upside down. Papers flying everywhere, drawers pulled out. A chaotic aftermath of a police search, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: A gang‚Äôs controlled area. Literally ‚Äúisland,‚Äù but used as ‚Äúmy turf.‚Äù
level6_yakuza.example: Koko wa ore no shima da. (This is my territory.)
level6_yakuza.prompt: 90s OVA style. Back view of a boss in a coat standing on a rooftop, overlooking a sprawling city at night with neon lights. "This is my city" vibe, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: A lower-ranking member who serves seniors. Strong hierarchy/loyalty nuance.
level6_yakuza.example: Shatei ni yari-naoshisaseta. (I made my junior redo it.)
level6_yakuza.prompt: Traditional Yakuza anime style. A younger member in a track suit bowing exactly 90 degrees to an older member in a suit. Respect and hierarchy, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: In yakuza terms, a respected senior (not your real uncle). Sounds gritty and old-school.

level6_yakuza.prompt: Character portrait style. An elderly man with gray hair and sunglasses, wearing a casual kimono, sipping tea calmly. An aura of dangerous wisdom, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: The top leader you swear loyalty to. Feels heavy and authoritative.

level6_yakuza.prompt: Heavy atmospheric anime style. A powerful man sitting on a fancy leather chair in a dimly lit room. Cigar smoke, gold jewelry, imposing presence, no text, no speech bubbles, no letters, no watermark, aspect ratio 16:9

level6_yakuza.explanation: A ceremonial exchange of sake cups to form a sworn relationship (classic yakuza trope).
level6_yakuza.example: Sakazuki wo kawashita. (We exchanged the oath cups.)
